_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Fill alarm at 79% w/auto. shut-off at 82%, min. Class I Div. 1 w/in 5 ft. of all tr./line br. Pts. (truck off-loading) with Class I Div. 2 from 5-15 ft., Syst. fails closed w/activ. of fire prot. Sys
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Hydrocarbon detector (offload, vessel and pump area), flow monitor along with temperature, pressure, and liquid level indicators

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Sunoco Logistics, L.P.
Delmont Terminal
RMP EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

At the Sunoco Logistics, L.P. (Sunoco Logistics) Delmont Terminal in Delmont, Pennsylvania, we are committed to providing a safe work environment for employees and to being a responsible corporate citizen. We believe that excellent performance in the areas of health, environment, safety and security goes hand-in-hand with operational excellence and financial success. In fulfilling this commitment, we will comply with regulatory requirements and provide and maintain a safe working environment using acceptable and proven business practices. All Sunoco Logistics employees will strive to identify and eliminate hazards which could result in injury and illness, damage to the environment, property damage, and security losses.

The Delmont Terminal is operated and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of our employees, contractors and the community in which we operate. We promote health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection. These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning. This summary provides a brief overview of the risk management activities that we have designed and implemented.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The Delmont Terminal is an onshore, bulk petroleum storage terminal used in the storage and distribution of petroleum products to retail and commercial end-users. The Terminal handles and stores various grades of unleaded gasoline, low-sulfur diesel, No. 2 fuel oil, propane, ethanol, and various other petroleum based additives.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAMS

Our accidental release prevention programs and emergency planning and response programs help us effectively manage the hazards posed by our regulated substances to our employees, the public, and the environment. The covered process is regulated

Title III. The programs are reviewed and updated on an annual basis, or more often if required. Our Emergency Response Plan provides the essential planning and training for protecting employees, the public, and the environment during emergency situations. Contained within the Plan are written procedures that outline the actions to be taken for various types of emergencies that could occur in the terminal. These emergencies may include: airborne releases of chemical substances, spills to the water or ground, fires, explosions, personnel medical emergencies. The Programs address the aspects of emergency response including:

-Information on emergency organization (Incident Command System), including roles and responsibilities of personnel responding to the incident
-Procedures for notifying employees that a release has occurred
-Procedures for plant evacuation and accounting of personnel
-Procedures to notify local emergency response organizations and other appropriate authorities that a release has occurred
-Guidance on proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures
-Procedures for post incident cleanup and decontamination

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

We are continually striving to make the Delmont Terminal the safest and most reliable workplace possible for our employees, our neighbors and our community. The facility's focus is safe, reliable, and environmentally sound operations. The goal of the Delmont Terminal is to demonstrate continuous improvement in our health, environmental and safety performance. In addition, we will work cooperatively with our neighbors and local 1st responders to ensure the health, environment, safety and security of the Delmont Terminal and surrounding community.

by the EPA Risk Management Program regulation 40 CFR Part 68, and the OSHA Process Safety Management standard 29 CFR 1910.119. The following accident prevention programs are in place at the Delmont Terminal:

1) Employee Participation
2) Process Safety Information
3) Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) with Risk Assessments
4) Standard Operating Procedures
5) EHS Operator Training
6) Contractors
7) Pre-startup Safety Review
8) Mechanical Integrity with Preventive Maintenance
9) Work Permits
10) Management of Change
11) EHS Accident or Potential Catastrophic Event Investigation
12) Emergency Response
13) Compliance Audits
14) Trade Secrets

OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

Offsite consequence analysis was performed to estimate the potential for an unexpected release of Propane that could affect the public or the environment. The offsite consequence analysis consisted of evaluating both worst-case scenarios and alternative case release scenarios. Sunoco Logistics has submitted these release scenarios to the United States Environmental Protection Agency.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Delmont Terminal has an excellent record of accident prevention. The terminal keeps records for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility. This is a new propane blending process; consequently, there have been no accidents within the past five (5) years resulting from the chemical release of materials covered under the EPA RMP regulation.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Response actions are coordinated with the Slickville Volunteer Fire Department and Westmoreland County LEPC (Westmoreland Department of Public Safety). A Facility Response Plan (FRP) is in place to inform employees what to do in case of a release, fire, and to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response.

The Delmont Terminal maintains compliance with local, state and federal regulations including OSHA 29 CFR 1910.120, Oil Pollution Act of 1990 and SARA
